translations.text: Nun. By the pen and what the scribes write.<sup foot_note="182226">1</sup>
By your Lord's Grace, you are not afflicted with madness,<sup foot_note="182227">1</sup>
and surely yours shall be a never-ending reward,<sup foot_note="182228">1</sup>
and you are certainly on the most exalted standard of moral excellence.<sup foot_note="182229">1</sup>
So you will soon see, and they too will see,
which of you is afflicted with madness.
Surely your Lord knows well those who have strayed from His Way just as He knows well those who are on the Right Way.
Do not, then, yield to those who reject the Truth, decrying it as false;
they would wish you to be pliant so that they too may be pliant.<sup foot_note="182230">1</sup>
And do not yield to any contemptible swearer,<sup foot_note="182231">1</sup>
the fault-finder who goes around slandering,
the hinderer of good,<sup foot_note="182232">1</sup> the transgressor, the sinful;<sup foot_note="182233">2</sup>
the coarse-grained, and above all mean and ignoble;<sup foot_note="182234">1</sup>
(who so acts) simply because he has wealth and sons,<sup foot_note="182235">1</sup>
and whenever Our verses are rehearsed to him, he says: “These are fairy- tales of times gone by.”
Soon shall We brand him on his snout.<sup foot_note="182236">1</sup>

We have put them [i.e., the Makkans] to test even as We put to test the owners of the orchard<sup foot_note="182237">1</sup> when they vowed that they would gather the fruit of their orchard in the morning,
without making any allowance (for the will of Allah).<sup foot_note="182238">1</sup>
Thereupon a calamity from your Lord passed over it while they were asleep,
and so by morning the orchard lay as though it had been fully harvested.
At daybreak they called out to one another:
“Hurry to your orchard<sup foot_note="182239">1</sup> if you would gather its fruit.”
So off they went, whispering to one another:
“No destitute person shall enter it today.”
They went forth early, believing that they had the power (to gather the fruit).<sup foot_note="182240">1</sup>
But as soon as they beheld the orchard, (they cried out): “We have certainly lost the way;
rather, we are utterly ruined.”<sup foot_note="181934">1</sup>
The best among them said: “Did I not say to you: why do you not give glory to (your Lord)?”<sup foot_note="181965">1</sup>
They cried out: “Glory be to our Lord! Certainly we were sinners.”
Then they began to reproach one another.<sup foot_note="182241">1</sup>
They said: “Woe to us! We had indeed transgressed.
Maybe our Lord will give us a better orchard in its place; to our Lord do we penitently turn.”
Such is the chastisement; and the chastisement of the Hereafter is assuredly even greater, if only they knew.
Surely<sup foot_note="182242">1</sup> the God-fearing shall have Gardens of bliss with their Lord.
What! Shall We treat those who have submitted (to Our command) like those who have acted as criminals?
What is the matter with you? How ill do you judge!<sup foot_note="182243">1</sup>
Or do you have a Book<sup foot_note="182244">1</sup> wherein you read
that (in the Hereafter) you shall have all that you choose for yourselves?
Or have We sworn a covenant with you which We are bound to keep till the Day of Resurrection, (a covenant requiring that whatever you ordain for yourselves shall be yours)?
Ask them: “Which of them can guarantee that?<sup foot_note="182245">1</sup>
Or has something been guaranteed by any of those whom they associate with Allah in His Divinity?” If so, let them bring forth their associates, if they are truthful.<sup foot_note="182246">1</sup>
On the Day when the dreadful calamity will unfold,<sup foot_note="182247">1</sup> when people will be summoned to prostrate themselves, and yet they will not be able to prostrate.
Their eyes shall be downcast and ignominy shall overwhelm them. For when they were safe and sound, they were summoned to prostrate themselves, (and they refused).<sup foot_note="182248">1</sup>

So leave Me, (O Prophet), to deal with him who gives the lie to this Discourse.<sup foot_note="182249">1</sup> We shall draw them little by little (to their undoing) in a way that they will not know.<sup foot_note="182250">2</sup>
I am giving them a respite. Great is My scheme!<sup foot_note="182251">1</sup>
Or are you asking them for some compensation so that they feel burdened with debt?<sup foot_note="182252">1</sup>
Or do they have any knowledge of the Unseen which they are now writing down?<sup foot_note="182253">1</sup>

So bear with patience until the Judgement of your Lord<sup foot_note="182254">1</sup> comes, and do not belike the man in the fish (i.e., Jonah)<sup foot_note="182255">2</sup> who called out, choking with grief:<sup foot_note="182256">3</sup>
had his Lord not bestowed His favour upon him, he would have been cast upon that barren shore (and would have remained there) in disgrace.<sup foot_note="182257">1</sup>
But his Lord exalted him, and included him among His righteous servants.

When the unbelievers hear this Exhortation, they look at you as though they would knock you off your feet with their (hostile) glances.<sup foot_note="182258">1</sup> They say: “Surely he is afflicted with madness”;
although this is nothing but an Exhortation (to goodness) for everyone in the world.
